adverb.description: Up until the present or a specified or implied time; by now or then.
examples: I haven't told anyone else yet
aren't you ready to go yet?
I have yet to be convinced
the congress was widely acclaimed as the best yet

adverb.description: Still; even (used to emphasize increase or repetition)
examples: snow, snow, and yet more snow
the rations were reduced yet again
every week she gets worse, and yet it could go on for years

conjunction.description: But at the same time; but nevertheless.
examples: the path was dark, yet I slowly found my way

phrases: Then he could not bear to look at it, nor yet to turn his back upon it.
The latter has neither been published nor yet given to the theatre.
Not Siberian cold, of course, nor yet Canadian or New England cold.
When I go to bed I put my head on the pillow, shut my eyes and drop straight off into a nice, healthy sleep, not too deep nor yet too shallow.
We don't know how long it will take, nor yet if we'll succeed.
origin: Old English gÄ«et(a), of unknown origin.
